title: CBSE Grade 7 MathQuest Core Curriculum
design_principles: Learning first: interactivity must reveal thinking, not just decorate answers.
Every atom has at least one transfer-style check (novel context) and one misconception probe.
Multiple representations (number line, area model, equation, table) are built into the item mix.
Short feedback loops: wrong answers map to repair items, not just 'try again'.

tracks.name: CBSE Core
tracks.focus: NCERT mastery, school exams, conceptual clarity

tracks.name: Olympiad Enrichment
tracks.focus: Non-routine reasoning, patterns, number theory, counting

modules.title: Problem-Solving Foundations (all chapters)
big_ideas: Good solvers represent the problem before calculating.
Checking is part of solving: estimate, use units, and reverse operations.
Explaining your reasoning makes your thinking stronger and reveals gaps.

atoms.title: Plan–Solve–Check (a repeatable routine)
atoms.core_idea: A simple routine reduces careless errors and increases understanding.

outcomes.statement: Identify what is asked, what is given, and what is unknown.
Choose a representation (number line, table, diagram, equation).
Check by estimation, units, or reverse operation.

atoms.title: Estimation & Reasonableness Checks
atoms.core_idea: Estimation is a safety net: your answer should make sense in size and units. Start with whole-number rounding; extend to decimals later.

outcomes.statement: Round numbers to estimate results quickly.
Detect unreasonable answers (wrong magnitude).
Use inverse operations to verify.

atoms.title: Explain Your Reasoning (short proofs)
atoms.core_idea: A short explanation uses a claim, evidence (math fact), and a conclusion.

outcomes.statement: Write a 1–2 sentence justification using a known fact.
Use sentence frames ('Because..., therefore...').
Identify missing steps in an explanation.

modules.title: Chapter 1: Integers
big_ideas: Integers extend whole numbers to include negatives and zero.
The number line is a map of magnitude; distance and direction matter.
Operations on integers can be understood as movement patterns, not memorized rules.

atoms.title: Integers on the Number Line (compare & order)
atoms.core_idea: Integers represent positions on a number line; to compare, look at who is to the right.

outcomes.statement: Place positive, negative, and zero on a number line.
Compare and order integers using >, <.
Explain why -3 is greater than -7 using the number line.

atoms.title: Add & Subtract Integers (as movement)
atoms.core_idea: Adding moves right/left on the number line; subtraction is adding the opposite.

outcomes.statement: Add integers using a number line model.
Subtract integers by rewriting as addition of the opposite.
Explain why subtracting a negative increases the value.

atoms.title: Multiply & Divide Integers (pattern + meaning)
atoms.core_idea: Signs in multiplication/division follow a consistent pattern that preserves arithmetic structure.

outcomes.statement: Multiply and divide integers correctly.
Justify sign rules using patterns (e.g., decreasing by 3).
Identify and correct common sign mistakes.

atoms.title: Order of Operations with Integers
atoms.core_idea: A standard order (brackets, exponents, multiplication/division, addition/subtraction) prevents ambiguity.

outcomes.statement: Evaluate expressions with integers using correct order of operations.
Use parentheses to change the value intentionally.
Spot and correct order-of-operations mistakes.

atoms.title: Absolute Value as Distance
atoms.core_idea: Absolute value measures distance from zero, not 'making a number positive' as a trick.

outcomes.statement: Interpret |a| as distance from 0.
Solve simple distance questions (e.g., distance between -3 and 5).
Avoid common absolute value misconceptions.

atoms.title: Integer Word Problems (Model + Check)
atoms.core_idea: A good model (number line or context table) plus a reasonableness check prevents sign errors.

outcomes.statement: Translate a word situation into integer operations.
Choose a representation (number line/table) and solve.
Check reasonableness using estimation or a reverse operation.

modules.title: Chapter 2: Fractions and Decimals
big_ideas: Fractions describe parts of a whole and ratios; equivalent fractions are the same value in different forms.
Magnitude matters: place fractions and decimals on a number line to reason, not guess.
Operations on fractions have meanings (scaling, sharing), not just rules.

atoms.title: Fractions: Meaning, Equivalence, Simplifying
atoms.core_idea: Equivalent fractions represent the same point on the number line; simplifying is dividing numerator and denominator by the same non-zero number.

outcomes.statement: Explain a fraction as a number (not two separate numbers).
Generate equivalent fractions using multiplication/division by the same number.
Simplify fractions using common factors.

atoms.title: Compare & Order Fractions and Decimals
atoms.core_idea: To compare, use benchmarks (0, 1/2, 1) or common denominators or convert to decimals.

outcomes.statement: Compare two fractions using benchmarks or common denominator.
Compare decimals using place value and number line.
Order a mix of fractions and decimals.

atoms.title: Add & Subtract Fractions (including mixed numbers)
atoms.core_idea: Fractions can only be added/subtracted when they refer to the same-sized parts (common denominator).

outcomes.statement: Add/subtract fractions with like denominators.
Add/subtract fractions with unlike denominators using LCM.
Handle mixed numbers by converting or separating whole and fractional parts.

atoms.title: Multiply Fractions (as scaling)
atoms.core_idea: Multiplying by a fraction scales a quantity; multiplying two fractions multiplies their parts.

outcomes.statement: Multiply a fraction by a whole number and by another fraction.
Simplify before multiplying using common factors.
Interpret multiplication by a fraction as scaling (smaller/bigger).

atoms.title: Divide Fractions (meaning + invert-and-multiply)
atoms.core_idea: Dividing by a fraction asks 'how many of this fraction fit in that quantity?'

outcomes.statement: Interpret division of fractions with a measurement model.
Compute fraction division using invert-and-multiply.
Check reasonableness (division by a fraction can increase the number).

atoms.title: Decimals: Place Value, Rounding, and Operations
atoms.core_idea: Decimals are fractions with denominators of powers of 10; place value controls size.

outcomes.statement: Convert between fractions (denominator 10/100/1000) and decimals.
Add/subtract decimals using alignment of place value.
Multiply/divide decimals by powers of 10; round and estimate to check.

modules.title: Chapter 3: Data Handling
big_ideas: Data tells a story; representation choices affect what you see.
Measures of center (mean/median/mode) summarize differently.
Good reasoning includes questioning misleading graphs.

atoms.title: Collect, Organize, and Read Data (frequency tables)
atoms.core_idea: A frequency table organizes counts and supports graphing and analysis.

outcomes.statement: Create a frequency table from raw data.
Read values from a table accurately.
Compute totals from frequencies.

atoms.title: Bar Graphs and Double Bar Graphs
atoms.core_idea: Bar graphs compare categories; double bars compare two groups on same categories.

outcomes.statement: Read and interpret bar graphs and double bar graphs.
Create a simple bar graph from a table (conceptually).
Answer comparison questions using the graph.

atoms.title: Mean, Median, Mode (and when to use which)
atoms.core_idea: Different averages summarize different aspects; choose based on context and outliers.

outcomes.statement: Compute mean, median, and mode for small data sets.
Explain when median might be better than mean.
Detect how an outlier changes mean vs median.

atoms.title: Range and Simple Interpretation
atoms.core_idea: Range captures spread; interpretation answers what the data suggests, not what you wish it said.

outcomes.statement: Compute range and compare spreads.
Make simple inferences from graphs/tables.
Distinguish observation from opinion.

atoms.title: Pie Charts (fractions of a whole)
atoms.core_idea: A pie chart represents parts of a whole; angle/sector size matches fraction/percent.

outcomes.statement: Read fractions/percents from a pie chart.
Convert between fraction/percent for pie slices.
Create (conceptually) a pie chart from data.

atoms.title: Misleading Graphs (critical thinking)
atoms.core_idea: Graphs can mislead through scale tricks or missing context; check axes and totals.

outcomes.statement: Spot misleading scales and truncated axes.
Explain how the graph could mislead.
Suggest a corrected graph.

modules.title: Chapter 4: Simple Equations
big_ideas: An equation states two expressions are equal; solving means finding the value that makes it true.
Valid moves preserve equality by doing the same operation to both sides.
Checking is part of solving, not an optional extra.

atoms.title: Equation as Balance (what 'solve' means)
atoms.core_idea: An equation is a balance; every legal move keeps both sides equal.

outcomes.statement: Explain what it means to solve an equation.
Identify whether a value satisfies an equation (check by substitution).
Distinguish expression vs equation.

atoms.title: Solve One-step Equations (x ± a = b)
atoms.core_idea: Undo addition/subtraction with the inverse operation on both sides.

outcomes.statement: Solve x + a = b and x − a = b.
Explain the inverse operation used.
Check the solution.

atoms.title: Solve One-step Equations (ax = b, x/a = b)
atoms.core_idea: Undo multiplication/division with inverse operation; keep equality by applying to both sides.

outcomes.statement: Solve ax = b and x/a = b (including negative a).
Use division/multiplication correctly.
Check solutions.

atoms.title: Solve Two-step Equations (ax + b = c)
atoms.core_idea: Undo operations in reverse order: first remove b, then divide by a.

outcomes.statement: Solve ax + b = c (including negatives).
Choose the correct undo order and justify it.
Check solutions.

atoms.title: Inequalities (intro) and Number Line Graphing
atoms.core_idea: An inequality describes a range of values; the number line shows the set of solutions.

outcomes.statement: Interpret symbols <, ≤, >, ≥.
Represent solutions on a number line.
Check whether a value satisfies an inequality.

modules.title: Chapter 5: Lines and Angles
big_ideas: Angle facts come from a few invariants (straight line 180°, around a point 360°).
Vertical angles are equal; linear pairs sum to 180°.
Diagram reasoning is about relationships, not guessing.

atoms.title: Angle Types and Measuring
atoms.core_idea: Angles measure turn; benchmark angles build estimation and sense-making.

outcomes.statement: Identify acute, right, obtuse, straight, reflex angles.
Estimate and measure angles.
Use 90°, 180°, 360° as benchmarks.

atoms.title: Angles on a Straight Line and Around a Point
atoms.core_idea: Angles on a straight line sum to 180°; around a point sum to 360°.

outcomes.statement: Solve missing angle problems using 180° and 360° facts.
Explain reasoning using sum facts.
Check by substitution (do sums).

atoms.title: Vertical Angles and Linear Pairs
atoms.core_idea: Vertical angles are equal; a linear pair sums to 180°.

outcomes.statement: Identify vertical angles and linear pairs in diagrams.
Compute unknown angles using equality/sum relations.
Explain which relationship you used.

atoms.title: Complementary and Supplementary Angles
atoms.core_idea: Complementary angles sum to 90°; supplementary sum to 180°.

outcomes.statement: Determine complements and supplements of given angles.
Use these relationships in simple problems.
Avoid mixing up 90° and 180°.

atoms.title: Angle Problem Solving (multi-step diagrams)
atoms.core_idea: Complex diagrams are solved by chaining small facts: equal angles, sums, and known benchmarks.

outcomes.statement: Solve multi-step angle problems with 2–3 relations.
Write a short explanation of the chain of reasoning.
Check with total sums.

modules.title: Chapter 6: The Triangle and its Properties
big_ideas: Triangle properties (angle sum 180°, side relationships) unlock many geometry problems.
Classifying triangles helps choose the right facts quickly.
Reasoning beats memorizing: justify every step.

atoms.title: Classify Triangles (by sides and angles)
atoms.core_idea: Triangles can be classified by side equality and angle type; classification reveals properties.

outcomes.statement: Classify triangles as scalene/isosceles/equilateral and acute/right/obtuse.
Identify triangle type from a diagram or measurements.
State one property of isosceles/equilateral triangles.

atoms.title: Angle Sum of a Triangle
atoms.core_idea: The interior angles of any triangle add to 180°.

outcomes.statement: Find missing angle in a triangle using 180° sum.
Solve problems involving two or more triangles.
Explain reasoning using angle sum.

atoms.title: Exterior Angle of a Triangle (intro)
atoms.core_idea: An exterior angle equals the sum of the two remote interior angles (and forms a linear pair with its adjacent interior angle).

outcomes.statement: Identify an exterior angle in a triangle.
Use linear pair (180°) to compute exterior/interior.
Use exterior angle property in simple problems.

atoms.title: Isosceles Triangle Base Angles
atoms.core_idea: In an isosceles triangle, angles opposite equal sides are equal.

outcomes.statement: Use equal sides to infer equal base angles.
Solve missing angle problems in isosceles triangles.
Explain 'opposite equal sides' clearly.

atoms.title: Triangle Inequality (intro)
atoms.core_idea: Three lengths form a triangle only if the sum of any two sides is greater than the third.

outcomes.statement: Determine if three lengths can form a triangle.
Explain using 'two sides must reach'.
Generate a valid third side range given two sides.

modules.title: Chapter 7: Congruence of Triangles
big_ideas: Congruence means 'same shape and size' (superimposable).
Triangle congruence criteria (SSS, SAS, ASA, RHS) let you prove equality without measuring everything.
CPCTC connects congruence to solving for unknown sides/angles.

atoms.title: Congruent vs equal vs similar (superimposition idea)
atoms.core_idea: Congruent figures can be placed exactly on top of each other by rigid moves (slide/turn/flip).

outcomes.statement: Identify congruent shapes in a set and justify why.
Distinguish 'equal length/angle' from 'congruent figure'.
Use rigid motions to explain congruence (no resizing).

atoms.title: Triangle congruence: SSS and SAS
atoms.core_idea: Three sides determine a triangle; two sides and included angle also determine it uniquely.

outcomes.statement: Apply SSS and SAS criteria to decide if triangles are congruent.
Identify 'included angle' correctly for SAS.
Use congruence criteria language in a proof outline.

atoms.title: Triangle congruence: ASA and RHS
atoms.core_idea: Two angles + a side fix a triangle; for right triangles, hypotenuse + one side (RHS) is enough.

outcomes.statement: Apply ASA and RHS criteria correctly.
Recognize right triangles and identify hypotenuse.
Explain why AAA does NOT prove congruence.

atoms.title: CPCTC: Use congruence to find unknown parts
atoms.core_idea: Once triangles are congruent, corresponding sides/angles are equal (CPCTC).

outcomes.statement: Match corresponding vertices correctly.
Compute missing sides/angles using CPCTC.
Avoid mixing up correspondence order.

modules.title: Chapter 8: Comparing Quantities
big_ideas: Percent is 'out of 100' and connects fractions and decimals.
Ratios compare quantities multiplicatively; unit rate simplifies comparisons.
Successive percent changes are not additive; order matters.

atoms.title: Percent, Fraction, Decimal Conversions
atoms.core_idea: Percent, fractions, and decimals are three forms of the same value; choose the form that makes thinking easiest.

outcomes.statement: Convert between percent, fraction, and decimal.
Use benchmarks (10%, 25%, 50%, 75%) for quick mental conversions.
Explain conversions using 'per 100'.

atoms.title: Find Percent of a Quantity
atoms.core_idea: A percent of a quantity is scaling: value × (percent/100).

outcomes.statement: Compute p% of a number using multiplication.
Use benchmark decomposition (e.g., 35% = 10% + 10% + 10% + 5%).
Estimate to check reasonableness.

atoms.title: Increase/Decrease, Discount, Tax, Successive Changes
atoms.core_idea: Percent change scales the original: new = original × (1 ± p/100). Successive changes compound.

outcomes.statement: Calculate final price after discount or increase.
Handle discount then tax (order matters).
Explain why 10% increase then 10% decrease is not 'back to original'.

atoms.title: Ratios and Rates (including unit rate)
atoms.core_idea: Ratios compare quantities multiplicatively; unit rate answers 'per 1'.

outcomes.statement: Write ratios in multiple forms (a:b, a/b, 'a to b').
Compute unit rate and compare options.
Use ratios to scale recipes or maps.

atoms.title: Proportion (missing value) and Scaling
atoms.core_idea: Proportional relationships keep the same multiplicative factor; scaling multiplies both terms by the same factor.

outcomes.statement: Solve missing-value proportion problems using scaling or cross-multiplication (later).
Decide if two ratios are equivalent.
Explain scaling factor in words.

atoms.title: Percent & Ratio Applications (choose the right model)
atoms.core_idea: Pick a model (percent multiplier, ratio table, unit rate) based on what the story is asking.

outcomes.statement: Identify whether a situation is percent, ratio, or rate.
Solve mixed application problems using an appropriate representation.
Explain why your chosen model fits.

modules.title: Chapter 9: Rational Numbers
big_ideas: Rational numbers include all numbers that can be written as p/q where q ≠ 0.
The number line organizes all rational numbers; between any two rationals there are infinitely many.
Properties (commutative, associative, distributive) help simplify and reason.

atoms.title: Rational Numbers on the Number Line
atoms.core_idea: Rational numbers include negative fractions and decimals; place them by magnitude, not by numerator/denominator separately.

outcomes.statement: Represent rational numbers (fractions/decimals) on the number line.
Compare and order negative fractions and decimals.
Convert between forms when helpful.

atoms.title: Add/Subtract Rational Numbers
atoms.core_idea: Rational addition/subtraction follows the same structure as integers; common denominators align parts.

outcomes.statement: Add/subtract rational numbers including negatives.
Use common denominators and sign reasoning correctly.
Check answers by estimating magnitude.

atoms.title: Multiply/Divide Rational Numbers
atoms.core_idea: Multiplication scales; division asks 'how many of this quantity fit'. Signs follow integer rules.

outcomes.statement: Multiply/divide rational numbers including negatives.
Simplify efficiently using cancellation.
Explain sign outcome using parity of negatives.

atoms.title: Properties of Operations (with examples & counterexamples)
atoms.core_idea: Properties (commutative/associative/distributive) are tools: use them when they simplify thinking.

outcomes.statement: Identify commutative and associative properties for + and ×.
Use distributive property to simplify computations.
Recognize operations where a property does NOT apply (subtraction/division).

atoms.title: Density of Rational Numbers (find a number between)
atoms.core_idea: Between any two different rational numbers, there exists another rational number (in fact, infinitely many).

outcomes.statement: Find a rational number between two rational numbers (using average or common denominators).
Explain why there are infinitely many between.
Use this idea to refine estimates on a number line.

modules.title: Chapter 10: Practical Geometry (Constructions)
big_ideas: Construction is not measurement: it uses rules (compass + straightedge) to create exact objects.
Parallel lines and triangle constructions rely on congruence ideas and angle properties.
Knowing the construction steps builds strong geometric thinking for higher grades.

atoms.title: Construction mindset: exactness, notation, and steps
atoms.core_idea: A construction is a sequence of justified steps; diagrams show intent, not artistic skill.

outcomes.statement: Distinguish construction vs drawing vs measurement.
Read common construction marks (arcs, equal segments, equal angles).
Write/choose the correct ordered steps for a simple construction.

atoms.title: Construct a line parallel to a given line through a point
atoms.core_idea: Parallel construction uses equal corresponding/alternate angles built from arcs.

outcomes.statement: Choose the correct method (copy an angle / use transversal).
Identify which angles must be equal to ensure parallel lines.
Order and justify steps.

atoms.title: Construct a triangle (SSS and SAS)
atoms.core_idea: Some sets of measurements determine a unique triangle; construction mirrors congruence logic.

outcomes.statement: Order the steps for SSS and SAS triangle constructions.
Identify 'included angle' for SAS construction.
Explain when a triangle cannot be constructed.

atoms.title: Construct a triangle (ASA and RHS)
atoms.core_idea: Angles plus a side fix a triangle; for right triangles, hypotenuse + one leg is enough.

outcomes.statement: Order steps for ASA construction.
Construct a right triangle given hypotenuse and one leg (RHS).
Identify when data is insufficient/ambiguous.

modules.title: Chapter 11: Perimeter and Area
big_ideas: Perimeter measures boundary length; area measures covered surface.
Formulas come from decomposing shapes into known parts.
Units are part of the answer; converting units is scaling.

atoms.title: Perimeter of Polygons
atoms.core_idea: Perimeter is the total distance around a shape; add side lengths carefully with units.

outcomes.statement: Compute perimeter of rectangles and general polygons.
Find unknown side lengths when perimeter is given.
Explain the difference between perimeter and area.

atoms.title: Area of Rectangle and Square (meaning + formula)
atoms.core_idea: Area counts unit squares; rectangle area = length × breadth.

outcomes.statement: Explain area as counting unit squares.
Compute area of rectangles/squares.
Solve for missing dimension given area.

atoms.title: Area of Triangle and Parallelogram (decompose)
atoms.core_idea: Triangle area is half a rectangle/parallelogram with same base and height; parallelogram area = base × height.

outcomes.statement: Compute area of a parallelogram using base and height.
Compute area of a triangle using 1/2 × base × height.
Identify base and height (perpendicular) correctly.

atoms.title: Composite Figures (add/subtract areas)
atoms.core_idea: Break complex shapes into rectangles/triangles; add or subtract areas carefully.

outcomes.statement: Decompose composite shapes into known parts.
Compute area of composite figures.
Explain your decomposition strategy.

atoms.title: Unit Conversions (length and area)
atoms.core_idea: Converting units is scaling; area conversions scale by the square of the length factor.

outcomes.statement: Convert between mm, cm, m, km (length).
Convert between cm² and m² (area) with correct scaling.
Detect unreasonable conversions with estimation.

modules.title: Chapter 12: Algebraic Expressions
big_ideas: Variables stand for numbers; algebra is generalized arithmetic.
Like terms can be combined because they represent the same 'unit'.
The distributive property links multiplication and addition, enabling expansion and factoring.

atoms.title: Variables & Translating Words to Expressions
atoms.core_idea: Translate situations into expressions by identifying the quantity and how it changes.

outcomes.statement: Represent an unknown with a variable.
Translate verbal statements to algebraic expressions.
Distinguish expression vs equation.

atoms.title: Terms, Coefficients, and Like Terms
atoms.core_idea: Like terms share the same variable part; you can combine only like with like.

outcomes.statement: Identify terms, coefficients, and constants.
Combine like terms correctly.
Explain why 3x + 2x works but 3x + 2 does not combine.

atoms.title: Distributive Property (Expand and Factor basics)
atoms.core_idea: Distribute multiplication across addition: a(b+c)=ab+ac; factoring reverses it.

outcomes.statement: Expand expressions like 3(x+4).
Factor simple expressions like 6x+12.
Explain distributive property using area/tiles.

atoms.title: Evaluate Expressions (Substitution)
atoms.core_idea: To evaluate, substitute the given value for the variable and follow order of operations.

outcomes.statement: Substitute values into expressions correctly (with parentheses).
Evaluate using order of operations.
Check reasonableness.

atoms.title: Patterns → Expressions (Generalization)
atoms.core_idea: A pattern can be described by a rule; algebra expresses the rule for any step number n.

outcomes.statement: Describe a pattern in words and as an expression in n.
Use a table to connect n to output.
Check the rule using multiple values.

modules.title: Chapter 13: Exponents and Powers
big_ideas: Exponents compress repeated multiplication into a powerful notation.
Exponent laws describe patterns; they are not arbitrary rules.
Powers of 10 connect to place value and estimation.

atoms.title: Meaning of Exponents (repeated multiplication)
atoms.core_idea: a^n means multiply a by itself n times; the exponent counts factors, not the value.

outcomes.statement: Write repeated multiplication using exponent notation and expand powers.
Evaluate small powers accurately.
Distinguish base and exponent.

atoms.title: Powers of 10 and Place Value
atoms.core_idea: 10^n shifts place value; it explains how decimals move when multiplying/dividing by powers of 10.

outcomes.statement: Evaluate powers of 10 and express numbers using them.
Multiply/divide by 10^n using place value reasoning.
Estimate large numbers using powers of 10.

atoms.title: Exponent Laws (same base)
atoms.core_idea: Exponent laws follow from counting factors: multiplying adds exponents; dividing subtracts.

outcomes.statement: Use product and quotient laws: a^m × a^n, a^m ÷ a^n (a≠0).
Use power of a power: (a^m)^n.
Explain laws using factor expansion for small cases.

atoms.title: Zero Exponent and Exponent 1 (why it works)
atoms.core_idea: To keep the quotient law consistent, a^0 must equal 1 (for a≠0); a^1 equals a.

outcomes.statement: State and use a^0 = 1 (a≠0) and a^1 = a.
Explain a^0 using patterns/quotient law.
Avoid the '0 means 0' misconception.

modules.title: Chapter 14: Symmetry
big_ideas: Symmetry is an invariant: some things stay the same under a transformation.
Transformations (reflect, rotate, translate) build spatial reasoning and proof habits.
Counting symmetry builds classification skills for shapes.

atoms.title: Line Symmetry (identify and draw)
atoms.core_idea: A line of symmetry splits a figure into mirror halves.

outcomes.statement: Identify lines of symmetry in common shapes.
Draw a line of symmetry when it exists.
Recognize when a shape has no line symmetry.

atoms.title: Rotational Symmetry (order)
atoms.core_idea: A figure has rotational symmetry if it matches itself after a rotation; the order counts how many matches in a full turn.

outcomes.statement: Identify if a shape has rotational symmetry.
Determine the order of rotational symmetry.
Connect order to rotation angle (360°/order).

atoms.title: Reflections on a Grid (coordinate-free)
atoms.core_idea: Reflection flips a figure across a mirror line; corresponding points are the same distance from the mirror.

outcomes.statement: Reflect a point/shape across a given line on a grid.
Identify corresponding points and equal distances.
Spot reflection errors (wrong distance or wrong side).

atoms.title: Translations and Rotations (grid moves)
atoms.core_idea: Translation slides without turning; rotation turns around a center point.

outcomes.statement: Translate shapes by a given vector (up/down/left/right).
Rotate shapes by 90° multiples on a grid (optional).
Describe transformations in words.

modules.title: Chapter 15: Visualising Solid Shapes
big_ideas: 3D solids can be understood through nets (unfolding) and views (projection).
Counting faces/edges/vertices builds structure awareness.
Volume measures how much space a solid occupies; for a cuboid, it's L×B×H.

atoms.title: Faces, Edges, Vertices (classify solids)
atoms.core_idea: A solid is described by faces (surfaces), edges (line segments), and vertices (corners).

outcomes.statement: Identify and count faces, edges, vertices for common solids.
Match nets to solids (intro).
Use precise vocabulary.

atoms.title: Nets of Cubes and Cuboids
atoms.core_idea: A net is a 2D pattern that folds into a 3D solid; edges must match and faces must not overlap when folded.

outcomes.statement: Identify valid nets of a cube/cuboid.
Predict which faces become adjacent when folded.
Spot invalid nets (overlap or mismatch).

atoms.title: Views of Solids (top/front/side)
atoms.core_idea: Different views show different faces; combining views reconstructs the solid.

outcomes.statement: Match a solid to its top/front/side views.
Count cubes from views in simple cases.
Explain ambiguity when views are insufficient.

atoms.title: Volume of Cuboid (intro)
atoms.core_idea: Volume counts unit cubes; for a cuboid, volume = length × breadth × height.

outcomes.statement: Explain volume as counting unit cubes.
Compute volume of cuboids.
Solve for a missing dimension given volume.

modules.title: Olympiad Enrichment: Probability (intro)
big_ideas: Probability measures how likely an event is, from 0 (impossible) to 1 (certain).
For equally likely outcomes: P(event)=favorable/total.
Experimental probability approaches theoretical probability with more trials.

atoms.title: Outcomes and Sample Space
atoms.core_idea: A sample space lists all possible outcomes; events are subsets of outcomes.

outcomes.statement: List outcomes for simple experiments (coin, die, spinner).
Identify events as sets of outcomes.
Count outcomes accurately.

atoms.title: Probability as a Fraction (equally likely)
atoms.core_idea: Probability is the fraction of outcomes that satisfy the event, when outcomes are equally likely.

outcomes.statement: Compute probability of simple events.
Express probability as fraction, decimal, or percent.
Interpret 0, 1, and 1/2 in context.

atoms.title: Complementary Events
atoms.core_idea: P(not A) = 1 − P(A).

outcomes.statement: Find probability of 'not event'.
Solve problems where complement is easier than direct counting.
Explain why probabilities add to 1.

atoms.title: Experimental Probability (simulate and interpret)
atoms.core_idea: Experimental probability = successes/trials; more trials usually stabilizes the estimate.

outcomes.statement: Run a simple simulation (coin/spinner) and compute experimental probability.
Compare experimental to theoretical probability.
Explain variation in small samples.

modules.title: Olympiad Enrichment: Number Theory Foundations
big_ideas: Divisibility, primes, and remainders create patterns you can reason about (not memorize).
Parity (odd/even) and modular thinking are powerful 'shortcut' tools.
Many Olympiad problems become easy when you look for invariants and constraints.

atoms.title: Divisibility tests and smart factor spotting
atoms.core_idea: Divisibility rules are pattern tools; factor spotting makes calculations lighter.

outcomes.statement: Use divisibility tests for 2,3,4,5,8,9,11 in reasoning.
Find HCF/LCM via prime factorisation and via reasoning shortcuts.
Explain why a divisibility test works for at least one rule (e.g., 3 or 9).

atoms.title: Parity (odd/even) and quick contradiction checks
atoms.core_idea: Odd/even reasoning rules out impossible cases fast.

outcomes.statement: Predict parity of sums/products without calculating fully.
Use parity to prove something cannot happen.
Spot hidden assumptions in 'always/never' claims.

atoms.title: Remainders and modular patterns (intro)
atoms.core_idea: Remainders repeat in cycles; spotting cycles prevents long computation.

outcomes.statement: Find remainders of large powers using cycles (mod 2,3,4,5,8,9,10).
Explain the idea of 'mod' as remainder class.
Solve simple remainder puzzles.

modules.title: Olympiad Enrichment: Counting & Combinatorics (intro)
big_ideas: Count systematically: cases, tables, and 'fix one thing, vary the rest'.
Avoid double counting by being explicit about order and uniqueness.
Many problems are easiest when you draw a small complete list and then generalise.

atoms.title: Systematic listing and casework
atoms.core_idea: A clean list beats clever guessing.

outcomes.statement: Create a case table for a counting problem.
Explain why your list is complete and non-overlapping.
Use symmetry to reduce cases when appropriate.

atoms.title: Basic permutations vs combinations (sense-making, not formulas)
atoms.core_idea: Order matters sometimes; the story decides.

outcomes.statement: Decide if order matters in a situation.
Solve small problems by reasoning and listing, then generalise patterns.
Avoid applying formulas blindly.

modules.title: Olympiad Enrichment: Geometry Challenges (angle chase & area reasoning)
big_ideas: Angle chasing is logic: use parallel lines, triangles, and straight lines strategically.
Area problems often simplify using cutting/rearranging and equal-height arguments.
A clean diagram and labeled information is half the solution.

atoms.title: Angle chase toolkit (repeatable moves)
atoms.core_idea: A small set of facts solves many Olympiad angle problems.

outcomes.statement: Use parallel-line angle relationships confidently.
Use triangle angle-sum and exterior angles.
Spot isosceles/equilateral cues and use them.

atoms.title: Area reasoning (equal base/height, cut & rearrange)
atoms.core_idea: Areas compare easily when heights or bases match; rearranging shapes reveals equality.

outcomes.statement: Compare areas without calculating full units.
Use equal height arguments for triangles/parallelograms.
Solve puzzle-like area problems with rearrangement.

modules.title: Olympiad Enrichment: Algebra & Patterns (non-routine)
big_ideas: Patterns become solvable when you translate them into tables, expressions, or invariants.
Algebra is a language for structure, not just 'x'.
Many Olympiad problems are about choosing a smart representation.

atoms.title: Build and test rules for sequences (table → expression)
atoms.core_idea: Use input-output thinking to describe patterns.

outcomes.statement: Generate the next terms from a rule and justify it.
Create a rule from a table (simple linear patterns).
Check a rule with multiple values.

atoms.title: Inequality sense (bounds, not exact answers)
atoms.core_idea: Sometimes you only need a range; bounds are powerful.

outcomes.statement: Use estimate bounds for sums/products.
Reason about min/max under simple constraints.
Explain why a value is impossible.

modules.title: Engineering Foundation: Coordinate Thinking (early)
big_ideas: Coordinates are addresses; graphs are stories of relationships.
Many engineering entrance topics later rely on comfort with the coordinate plane.
You can start with simple plotting and patterns without formal 'functions'.

alignment.goal: Long-run bridge toward coordinate geometry used in higher classes.

atoms.title: Plot and read points in the coordinate plane (Quadrant I first)
atoms.core_idea: A point (x,y) means 'x along, y up'.

outcomes.statement: Plot points with positive coordinates accurately.
Read coordinates from a grid.
Connect coordinate changes to movement.

atoms.title: See linear patterns on a table and on a graph
atoms.core_idea: Tables and graphs show the same relationship in different clothes.

outcomes.statement: From a table, spot constant add pattern.
Plot the table as points and describe the trend.
Predict the next value and justify.

modules.title: Engineering Foundation: Calculation Fluency (smart, not speed)
big_ideas: Entrance exams reward accuracy and efficiency; efficiency comes from strategies, not rushing.
Mental math shortcuts reduce cognitive load so you can think.
Estimation prevents silly mistakes.

alignment.goal: Build fluency that supports later competitive prep without increasing anxiety.

atoms.title: Estimation and sanity-checks (units, order of magnitude)
atoms.core_idea: A quick estimate catches many wrong answers.

outcomes.statement: Estimate products/quotients using rounding.
Check if an answer is reasonable using units and magnitude.
Use reverse operation to check equations.

atoms.title: Strategy toolkit: distributive, factoring, fraction sense
atoms.core_idea: Algebraic thinking starts as arithmetic strategy.

outcomes.statement: Use distributive property for mental multiplication (e.g., 17×6 = (10+7)×6).
Simplify fraction calculations before multiplying/dividing.
Explain your shortcut.
